t: Proverbs 11
Dishonest*pn scales are detestable to the Lord,*s but*ln an accurate weight is his delight.
When*pn arrogance comes, disgrace follows, but*ln with humility comes wisdom.
The*pn integrity of the upright guides them, but*ln the perversity of the treacherous destroys them.
Wealth*pn is not profitable on a day of wrath, but*ln righteousness rescues from death.
The*pn righteousness of the blameless clears his path, but*ln the wicked person will fall because of his wickedness.
The*pn righteousness of the upright rescues them, but*ln the treacherous are trapped by their own desires.
When*pn the wicked person dies, his*ln expectation comes to nothing, and*ln hope placed in wealth vanishes.
The*pn righteous one is rescued from trouble; in*ln his place, the wicked one goes in.
With*pn his mouth the ungodly destroys his neighbor, but*ln through knowledge the righteous are rescued.
When*pn the righteous thrive, a city rejoices; when*ln the wicked die, there is joyful shouting.
A*pn city is built up by the blessing of the upright, but*ln it is torn down by the mouth of the wicked.
Whoever*pn shows contempt for his neighbor lacks sense, but*ln a person with understanding keeps silent.
A*pn gossip goes around revealing a secret, but*ln a trustworthy person keeps a confidence.
Without*pn guidance, a people will fall, but*ln with many counselors there is deliverance.
If*pn someone puts up security for a stranger, he*ln will suffer for it, but*ln the one who hates such agreements is protected.
A*pn gracious woman gains honor, but*ln violent people gain only riches.
A*pn kind man benefits himself, but*ln a cruel person brings ruin on himself.
The*pn wicked person earns an empty wage, but*ln the one who sows righteousness, a true reward.
Genuine*pn righteousness leads to life, but*ln pursuing evil leads to death.
Those*pn with twisted minds are detestable to the Lord,*s but*ln those with blameless conduct are his delight.
Be*pn assured that a wicked person will*ln not go unpunished, but*ln the offspring of the righteous will escape.
A*pn beautiful woman who rejects good sense is*ln like a gold ring in a pigâ€™s snout.
The*pn desire of the righteous turns out well, but*ln the hope of the wicked leads to wrath.
One*pn person gives freely, yet*ln gains more; another*ln withholds what is right, only*ln to become poor.
A*pn generous person will be enriched, and*ln the one who gives a drink of water will*ln receive water.
People*pn will curse anyone who hoards grain, but*ln a blessing will come to the one who sells it.
The*pn one who searches for what is good seeks favor, but*ln if someone looks for trouble, it will come to him.
Anyone*pn trusting in his riches will fall, but*ln the righteous will flourish like foliage.
The*pn one who brings ruin on his household will*ln inherit the wind, and*ln a fool will be a slave to*ln someone whose heart is wise.
The*pn fruit of the righteous is a tree of life, but*ln a cunning person takes lives.
If*pn the righteous will be repaid on earth, how*ln much more the wicked and sinful.
